body:
Yeah, I was thinking

1. Proto changes
2. Schema Registry
3. Default Implementation

The funny thing is that this is how my branches were originally organized.
I didn't know how to submit dependent PRs so I merged them all into one
branch. I'll leave this one here for reference and re-split them up.

-Dave

On Mon, Feb 12, 2018 at 2:02 PM, Ivan Kelly <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> And maybe the bookkeeper schema storage implementation can be a separate
> patch too?
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were assigned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/pull/1137#issuecomment-365060799>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAh9Fv77W3EyeSuedhJb4baAAo-NXnkwks5tUKbugaJpZM4RxagU>
> .
>

Yes, github really sucks at this. gerrit does it much better.

What I do these days is to create a larger WIP patch which has everything and is there for reference. Then I push one patch at a time. The review velocity isn't so high that having multiple patches out for review makes much sense anyhow. Once an out for review patch is merged, I then merge master into my WIP branch, and break off another chunk.

sounds good. I can easily break this apart again.

wrote:

Huge +1. I’ve been worried about this.

IIRC, we pass a string literal “SSL” as an argument somewhere else, and probably we can pass “TLS1.2” instead. Maybe we should fix it too.

I think the class name `Backend` and `BackendData` are ambiguous.
As these handle only zookeeper's data, these should be named `zkBackendData` or something.

> I think the class name Backend and BackendData are ambiguous.

or, we can use `InternalConfiguration/InternalData` instead of Backend because for topic's internal stats we use `internal-stats` term so, internal may give more meaning?
retest this please
This patch addresses #1211
@jai1 @merlimat @mgodave
@merlimat

@jai1 You may want to read these. If I understand correctly, HTTP entrypoints, which use `SecurityUtility::createSslContext`, may accept any protocol versions, even if we change the string to "TLS1.2".

https://docs.oracle.com/javase/9/docs/api/javax/net/ssl/SSLContext.html#getInstance-java.lang.String-
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/9/docs/specs/security/standard-names.html#sslcontext-algorithms
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/43481010/how-to-enable-only-tlsv1-2-on-java-8-server-application?noredirect=1&lq=1
@zhaijack : can you address @merlimat and @ivankelly 's comments? we need this change for function worker.
Thanks, have resolved all the comments, and fixed rebase conflict.
retest this please

@yush1ga @rdhabalia the combination of zkservers and ledgersrootpath is actually the "bookkeeper service url", zkservers indicates where pulsar stores its metadata and globalZooKeeperServers indciates where pulsar stores policies data. so all these 3 settings together are actually describe the "backend" for pulsar brokers.

the purpose of this PR is to provide a method for application to know which zk, bk that a pulsar cluster is using. I am fine with changing the name to a proper name that you think it is better.

so which name I should be using?

InternalConfiguration/InternalData ?
Or? 

If we can get a consensus about the naming, I can make the modification.

/cc @merlimat
Looks good to me, someone with permissions will have to review it though.
@merlimat I have addressed your comments, please take another round of review. If this looks good for you, I will rebase it to latest master.
I need to fixup tests on this, I think some mocks are missing implementations

> the purpose of this PR is to provide a method for application to know which zk, bk that a pulsar cluster is using.
InternalConfiguration/InternalData ?

I think we can add more configurations other than zk in future as it can surface internal configuration. So, should can keep it a generic  name eg: `InternalConfiguration`?
Okay will change it to InternalConfiguration
This is ready for review. Once this is finalized and merged, I'll start converting all the code to use new API.

@sijie Change looks good, though there's still the issue at https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/pull/1156/files#r167413443 . I think is using the `consumerId` of the active consumer to decide if other consumers are active/inactive, but we cannot compare `consumerId` across consumers.

The other comment was around making the Listener interface name more neutral so that we can add more event handlers, if (and when) the need arises, without having to add an additional listener.
Fixed in #1230
opened issue #1237 tracking using builder to create topics consumer.
@merlimat  @ivankelly, Thanks for your comments,  Would you please help review it again?
I don't see any client changes in this. How is a schema set for a topic?
@lucperkins do you have time on helping with the FAQ content here?
@rdhabalia @yush1ga I renamed "backend" to "internalConfiguration". Can you guys review this change again?
Client changes are dependent on #987 which is stalled waiting on #1089. As far as this PR is concerned the REST api is the only way to specify a schema.

> Does this provide a way to figure out the current active consumer? 

Not right now, I think it would be interesting to mention who's the active consumer in the topic in the topics stats. We could have a `Boolean` field in the `ConsumerStats` that is set to `null` in non-failover subscriptions.

> This could also have been done by each consumer periodically adding a message to the topic. if you start getting the messages, you are the active consumer.

@ivankelly : yes that's the trick we are using now for the other project.
rebased to the latest master

the CI failed with license header. fixed license header.

I forgot another item to make CPP client ignore this notification.
Closing since both #1135 & #1140 were merged in 1.22
@rdhabalia @yush1ga can any of you review this again?
LGTM.. just few minor comments..

I don't think 403 suits this case because the code is for authentication and authorization, technically. And 4xx errors are basically caused by client side. If server side limitation is the cause, 5xx should be used. 503 would be a best choice. However, if some bad client is requesting too many requests, 429 would be another option.
retest this please
retest this please
It makes sense. I have changed the status code to 503.
retest this please
retest this please
retest this please
retest this please

Sorry to be commenting on a closed issue, but I wanted to ask how *cheap* is it to create a non-persistent topic? Would it be able to handle the use case of a one off request/reply? The client subscribes to a randomly named non-persistent topic, it publishes a request to a topic and includes the *reply* topic name expecting the consumer to send back a message on that topic at some point.

I am currently using [NATS](https://github.com/nats-io/gnatsd) for this use case, but Pulsar would be very attractive if it can handle both cheap non-persistent topics and fully durable ones.

In the code review, @merlimat mentioned this:

```
I would suggest to just rename PartitionedConsumerImpl, change the constructor to accept a list of topics (rather than the number of partitions) and switch to use TopicMessageIdImpl. I don't think that UnAckedMessageTracker usage would need to be changed.

That would avoid to add a lot of new code and having to merge it later.
```
Rebased to fix tls test certificates issue
retest this please
retest this please

@massakam One thing that might also help is to include the producer/consumer exception message in the 500 error. That might help to quickly find out what the issue is (on the websocket proxy side) without having to search the proxy logs.

@merlimat - have addressed your review comments
Had to change the ports data type to integer else you get 
```
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: failed to initialize servicePort field while setting value 
	at org.apache.pulsar.common.util.FieldParser.lambda$update$0(FieldParser.java:126)
	at java.util.Spliterators$ArraySpliterator.forEachRemaining(Spliterators.java:948)
	at java.util.stream.ReferencePipeline$Head.forEach(ReferencePipeline.java:580)
	at org.apache.pulsar.common.util.FieldParser.update(FieldParser.java:120)
	at org.apache.pulsar.common.configuration.PulsarConfigurationLoader.create(PulsarConfigurationLoader.java:89)
	at org.apache.pulsar.common.configuration.PulsarConfigurationLoader.create(PulsarConfigurationLoader.java:73)
	at org.apache.pulsar.common.configuration.PulsarConfigurationLoader.create(PulsarConfigurationLoader.java:54)
	at org.apache.pulsar.proxy.server.ProxyServiceStarter.<init>(ProxyServiceStarter.java:79)
	at org.apache.pulsar.proxy.server.ProxyServiceStarter.main(ProxyServiceStarter.java:127)
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Can not set int field org.apache.pulsar.proxy.server.ProxyConfiguration.servicePort to null value
	at sun.reflect.UnsafeFieldAccessorImpl.throwSetIllegalArgumentException(UnsafeFieldAccessorImpl.java:167)
	at sun.reflect.UnsafeFieldAccessorImpl.throwSetIllegalArgumentException(UnsafeFieldAccessorImpl.java:171)
	at sun.reflect.UnsafeIntegerFieldAccessorImpl.set(UnsafeIntegerFieldAccessorImpl.java:80)
	at java.lang.reflect.Field.set(Field.java:764)
	at org.apache.pulsar.common.util.FieldParser.lambda$update$0(FieldParser.java:124)
```

I will make changes to the broker side and Discovery Configuration as a part of  a separate PR
retest this please

I’m also fine with using `null` as “disabled” but how are we going to deal with default values/behavior?

I didn’t read the details but my expectation was:
-1: Disabled
null: Default value (can be -1)
0: Invalid
gt 0: Enabled with the specified port number
@jai1 @rdhabalia I think this should be included in 1.22.0 as well.
(I have the change for 1.22 branch already ready to backport, will do once this is merged)

I think based  on the few past performance tests, we realized that bundle with 1K topic doesn't have much performance impact and if user creates topic with > 1K partitions then [Load-manager](https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-broker-common/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/broker/ServiceConfiguration.java#L370) will split the bundle if bundle has some good amount of traffic. Actually, adding more bundles will add more znodes in zookeeper and we may want to avoid zk-node creation if it doesn't require.?
retest this please
@jai1 I have added the tests.

Sorry for reviving this old issue, but I had the same issue using Java+Gradle with the 1.21.0-incubating client and what fixed it for me was using the JAR instead of the NAR for the pulsar-checksum dependency.
@merlimat @sijie
@jai1 This would be a candidate for 1.22.x.
Hm, maybe the test case is wrong?

I think that the max-producers/consumers per topic makes a lot of sense as a broker setting, since it protects it, but I don't see much value in having a namespace level override for this. 

If having unlimited producers on a topic is bad for the broker, we shouldn't allow a tenant to override the setting and allow it.
@jai1 Backported into 1.22
retest this please

> If a topic is created with huge number of partitions, it would be good to increase number of bundles by default. 

It is already the default behavior, though it happens after the creation of all the partitions, since before there's no way how many will be created. 

The default setting is to keep "splitting" bundles until there are < 1K topics/partitions in each. By default, too, we force unload of those bundles to spread them across available brokers. 

One thing that is not really clear from the documentation is how to prepare upfront for this kind of scenarios and create multiple bundles when creating the namespace.

> It is already the default behavior, though it happens after the creation of all the partitions, since before there's no way how many will be created.

I am not very sure that I understand this part. Do you mean the bundle was splitted when a partitioned topic created? or do you mean the bundle are splitted when all the partitions are actually created (or touched)?

I was more thinking having a "max" bundles to pre-split, after "max" bundles, it will keep "splitting" bundles until there are < 1k topics/partitions (also might be worth making 1k configurable). that means if I created a topic with 4k partitions, it can split the bundles to "max" bundles for example 1k bundles during the topic creation. This might be much better for the use cases that have high number of partitions: split during creation vs split during runtime.

or it might be good to have a large number for default bundles?

Hi @David-Jin, yes indeed there is a relationship.

The system described in the PNUTS paper was then productionized with the name Sherpa ([1], [2]). What was described as Yahoo Message Broker was eventually implemented as a different system and served Sherpa replication for multiple years, until it got replaced in production by Pulsar ~2 years ago.

> Is there any plans to open PNUTS project ?

Since I'm not at Yahoo anymore I don't have insight or voice in that :). I'll turn the question to @joefk @msb-at-yahoo 

 * [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yahoo_Sherpa
 * [2] https://yahooeng.tumblr.com/post/120730204806/sherpa-scales-new-heights
@maskit I would say to not backport it to 1.22 at this point, because we have not seen problems in practice that could be related to this bug.

> This might be much better for the use cases that have high number of partitions: split during creation vs split during runtime.

Yes, ideally if one creates a topic with 4000 partitions.. it would be better to have enough bundles before the user starts using them. 
Currently the problem is that the "create-partitioned-topic" operation just sets the metadata and the partitions are actually created when producers/consumers connect.

We could improve the `create-partitioned-topic` op to actually ensure there are enough bundles.

> or it might be good to have a large number for default bundles?

That is possible in 2 ways : 
  * `defaultNumberOfNamespaceBundles=4` in `broker.conf`
  * `pulsar-admin namespaces create $MY_NAMESPACE --bundles 64`

In both cases, we need documentation for one to understand what is that and why it matters.

> We could improve the create-partitioned-topic op to actually ensure there are enough bundles.

ah, that's what I meant to request for this issue.

> We could improve the `create-partitioned-topic` op to actually ensure there are enough bundles.

My take is, splitting bundle should not only depend on number of topics in it but it should also consider total traffic that bundle is serving. LoadManager considers multiple variables in split-bundle strategy (eg: msgRate, totalSession, bandwidth). So, I may not want to split bundle if it has 5K topics but has very less traffic and in other usecase, I may want to split bundle if it has <1K topics but has large traffic consistently which requires high resources from broker. So, shouldn't we avoid creating multiple bundles upfront but we should decide bundle-splitting based on resources that bundle requires.?

@rdhabalia I think the tradeoff here is whether you pay the penalty of spitting bundles at creation time or at runtime. I agreed splitting is definitely better on resources. However it is also good for users to do "pre-split" at creation time before run. 

I am wondering can we have some sort of split policies, that allows people can pre-split at creation time?

fyi. 

this is the logic attempts to dump configuration as json string

https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-client/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/client/impl/ConsumerStats.java#L101

@estebangarcia 

yeah. I think gradle has different resolver on resolving NAR dependency than maven. you have to use jar than nar for pulsar-checksum dependency.
Got it. I'll ping you after I fix the test.
I think that the language needs some polishing and I'd like to put together a specialized template to present the FAQ. But @sijie, I'd say let's accept the PR for now and I can do that work later.

@lucperkins that sounds good to me. 

@merlimat @rdhabalia any objections to accept this PR first? then @lucperkins can work on the FAQ template and polishing the language.

@lucperkins  I think the biggest problem is with the 2nd layer. Eg: when doing `pulsar-admin namespaces` that dumps the whole list of commands with all the options. 

I agree that here `Operations about brokers` doesn't really add much context over the `brokers` subcommand name.

But for example, at the 2nd level it would be good to hide all subcommands options, though keeping the subcommand description. 

Eg: if I run `pulsar-admin namespaces` I get a long list of sub-sub-commands, many of which might be a bit cryptical. (Even current doc is very terse.. but that's a separate story).

When running that command, I think it would be good to have a list of sub-command with brief description. 
```
    list      Get the namespaces for a property
    list-cluster      Get the namespaces for a property in a cluster
    destinations      Get the destinations for a namespace
    policies      Get the policies of a namspace
    unload      Unload a namespace from the current serving broker
    split-bundle      Split a namespace-bundle from the current serving broker
....
```

The other problem I see is that if I put wrong arguments, the help from the upper level is printed.. 

For example, if I don't know the options when creating a namespace, I could do:

```
bin/pulsar-admin namespaces create --help
```

or just

```
bin/pulsar-admin namespaces create
```

In both cases, the whole `bin/pulsar-admin namespaces` help is being printed, and I have to seek `create` between all of that..
maybe we should just rewrite CLI tools in Python and call it a day 🚶

@merlimat 
> If having unlimited producers on a topic is bad for the broker, we shouldn't allow a tenant to override the setting and allow it.

I agree it.

Then, how about restricting this command to only superUser like DispatchRate?
https://github.com/apache/incubator-pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-broker/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/broker/admin/impl/NamespacesBase.java#L587
Thank you for backporting!

In our case, a tenant made a bug that consumers are increase infinitely.
I think namespace level setting is useful for a tenant to detect the behavior they don't expect.
retest this please

> Then, how about restricting this command to only superUser like DispatchRate? 

For dispatch rate, there are many cases in which you might want to set this to a lower value than the broker defined value (which by default is unlimited). 
I think that even there, if a broker-wide setting is provided, we shouldn't be able to set it lower than the broker setting.

> In our case, a tenant made a bug that consumers are increase infinitely.
> I think namespace level setting is useful for a tenant to detect the behavior they don't expect.

Wouldn't the broker level setting protect in this case as well?
/cc @jerrypeng
ping @merlimat @rdhabalia ?
ping @ivankelly can you take a look at the latest change, so that we can move forward with this feature for 2.0 release.
@zhaijack Since the consumer builder changes went in already, please update the API to just be available through the builder.
@merlimat, Thanks for the reminder, will do the change for builder.
PR #1269 is for this
